title: Understanding the Lewis Structure
text: To determine the bond angle, molecular shape, and polarity, start by drawing the Lewis structure of NH₂⁻. Remember that nitrogen typically forms three bonds and has one lone pair in this ion.

title: Determining the Bond Angle
text: Consider the electron pair geometry around the nitrogen atom. The presence of a lone pair affects the bond angle. What is the typical bond angle for a molecule with a similar structure?

title: Identifying the Molecular Shape
text: The molecular shape is determined by the positions of the atoms, not the lone pairs. With two hydrogen atoms and one lone pair, what shape does the molecule take?

title: Checking for Polar Bonds
text: A polar bond occurs when there is a difference in electronegativity between the bonded atoms. Consider the electronegativity of nitrogen and hydrogen. Is there a significant difference?

title: Determining Overall Polarity
text: To determine if the molecule is polar, consider both the shape and the presence of polar bonds. Does the shape allow for the dipoles to cancel out, or do they add up to create a net dipole moment?
